text: From a 22 oz bottle into a North Coast chalace. Pours brown with head and lace. Aroma of pumpkin pie, coffee, cinnamon, nutmeg, rich malts. Medium carbonation and mouthfeel. Flavors of nutmeg, malts, cinnamon, coffee, minerals, pumpkin juice. Overall bold, unique, amazing aroma, modest malt body but tasty.

Deep brown with a tan head. Strong aroma of pumpkin and coffee. I dont even like coffee. Even. Bit this is delicious. Its more like chocolate cinnamon pumpkin flavor than coffee. Thats why its awesome. A real winter beer. Thank God its 82 in Hawaii right now, but Ive got my long sleeves on.
Tap at Grizzlys. This is hella good. Dark amber pour, soapy head. Coffee and sweet pumpkin pie spices. Well balanced. Yum.
Murky brownish orange. Sweet pumpkin and spice with light coffee. Flavor is more sweet pumpkin, layered spice, mild coffee and light roast.

Courtesy of 5000 via trade
Bottle: The aroma has moderate-heavy pumpkin pie spices, light-moderate roast, faint chocolate, and coffee. It pours an orange tinted dark brown with a two finger tan had that fades to a minimal film outlined by a thick ring. The flavor starts with light-moderate chocolate and caramel. There is some light roasted malt in the middle. The finish has light-moderate pumpkin pie spice (cinnamon is strongest) and mild coffee. Its medium bodied with light-moderate carbonation.

Shared bomber poured to a snifter showing an amber highlighted brown tone, with a presentable layer of tan head froth, and foamy spots of lacing. The nose was roasted, cocoa & coffee, a bit of nuttiness, and pronounced cinnamon. Medium bodied, with decent carbonation, the taste was similar notes, a bit of dryness, and some roasted & earthy bitterness. Pumpkin seemed a bit player at best, hidden by the coffee and spices, but otherwise, a very tasty & drinkable brew.

Bottle. It poured a dark brown color with a tan head. The aroma was of pumpkin, coffee and some nutmeg. The taste was similar to the aroma with more roasted coffee, cinnamon, pumpkin, nutmeg and allspice. Really tasty.

Draught at the Republic, Minneapolis, MN. Thanks Derek!
Dark reddish brown color with a small off-white head. 
Coffee, dark malt and spices in the aroma. 
Filtered coffee, sweetness, dark malt and spices in the flavor. 
No, no, no. Not my thing.

Pour is a dark brown with a large tan head. Aroma is a decent equal mix of pumpkin pie spice and coffee. Flavor is the same. Not a over the top spice and not a over the top coffee. Both are there and equally noticable. A little more coffee than spice is left on the tongue after the swallow. This is pretty solid and a different take on a pumpkin beer.

Sampled from the tap at the Republic Seven Corners. Pours a clear dark brown with a tan head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a combination of dark grains, roasted makes and pumpkin spice with a hint of coffee underlying. Flavor showcases more coffee with a good amount of coffee and dark grains with roasted malts supporting.

Pours a medium light brown with a thick luxuriant beige head from growler at Tap That. Nose is cimmamon, pumpkin spice, and coffee. Flavor sweet cinnamon and nutmeg, dark chocolate, and some coffee. Long lingering fresh coffee and bittersweet coffee. Very cozy tasting brew.

Bomber pours dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is balanced, coffee, pumpkin or yam, pie spices, cinnamon and whatnot. Starts with espresso then has a mildly sweet pumpkin pie finish. Medium bodied and smooth with soft carbonation. Very good pumpkin beer.

On tap. Pours a dark brown with a thin tan head. Aroma of cinnamon, mocha, nutmeg, chocolate malt. Flavor of lots of cinnamon, nutmeg, pumpkin spices, light coffee, roasted malt. Lots of cinnamon in this one. Coffee is there but not super dominant. Tasty!
7/4/8/4/15 (3.8/5)

Pours a medium brown. Looks pretty clear but dark enough that you cant see through the glass. Head is relatively thin but it continues to build from the bottom. Aroma of cinnamon, nutmeg, pumpkin spice and pumpkin, as one might expect. The aroma doesnt have much coffee to it, but maybe there is some chocolate. It smells fricken delicious. The coffee comes through a lot more in the flavor. This beer does taste like a pumpkin latte. I usually wouldnt like a beer this sweet and with this much non-traditional beer flavor, but this actually works pretty well. For the amount of flavor, it is still pretty drinkable and clean in the mouth. Good effort on this one. If you like this type of non-traditional beer this is one to try for sure.

22 ounce bottle. Translucent cola brown color topped by a small firm beige head. Big spicy malt nose, redolent of cinnamon and coffee. First sip brings more cinnamon and creamy cappuccino flavor. A smooth creamy mouthfeel as well. Coffee flavor dominates the palate, but the pumpkin pie spices are there. Mostly cinnamon and a hint of nutmeg and allspice. Rich, malty notes in finish. A decent effort. One of the better pumpkin beers tasted.

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2016 Sampled on draft at Smokin Joe?s this beer poured a dark brown color with a small foamy beige head that left minimal lacing. The aroma was sweet caramel and pumpkin spice. The flavor was sweet cinnamon sugar, nutmeg, vanilla cream and roasted caramel. Long finish. Moderately full bodied. Well done

Draft at Elysian Capitol Hill. Pours clear nut brown with a fizzy beige head. Smells like cinnamon, pumpkin, vanilla, booze, and roasted coffee. Tastes like cinnamon, pumpkin, roasted coffee beans, and vanilla. Light/medium body and low carbonation.

Tasted from bottle. Pours a hazy dark brown with a whit head. Aroma is cinnamon, nutmeg, and faint coffee. Taste is a very well balanced moderately sweet spiced pumpkin beer. More coffee and smoked malt on flavor than aroma with a cinnamon, nutmeg, pumpkin flavor that is not a spice bomb like some. Excellent pumpkin beer. One of the best I've had. Would love to try this against Warlock. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Pours black. Aroma and taste are largely coffee with pumpkin and spices.
Chestnut brown in color with a tan colored head. Aroma of coffee and pumpkin. Flavor followed with cinnamon and nutmeg. Mouthfeel moderate in body but nicely carbonated.

22 oz bottled 7 months ago, purchased at Tower Liquors. Hazy brown appearance with a tan head and plenty of sediment. Spiced up aroma with cinnamon, nutmeg, coffee and earth. Similar flavor, tasting slightly off, a little old and musty. Otherwise, not too bad for a shelf turd.

Big bottle. Fridge chilled. Served in tulip glass. Minimal head. Spotty lacing. Head is light tan, beer is darker brown. Aroma is mostly spices with some sweetness and light malts. Taste is medium sweet with a slight bitterness. Notes of spices amd capucinno and light malts. Medium bodied with light to medium carbonation. Overall an beer worthy of tasting.

Poured from a bottle. Color is dark amber with some sediment. Aroma is wonderful with cinnamon leading the way along with nutmeg, coffee, and pumpkin. Taste is more mild, but along the same lines as the aroma with some tailing bitterness and less cinnamon. Overall a very good pumpkin beer. More complex than most with great flavors to go with the pumpkin.

Perhaps my favorite pumpkin beer of all time. Aroma is pumpkin pie spice and coffee, taste follows, but its neither some turbo-boosted coffee stout nor a Southern Tier/Shorts style sweetness bomb. Really balanced and just delicious.

Draught @ Draught 55. Inky black with small foamy beige head, sharp coffee beans aroma, medium carbonation, bitter coffee taste with a hint of pumpkin flavor, medium bitter coffee finish. Strong coffee dominance with too little pumpkin.

Appearance- Clear ruby brown with a off white head. Fluffy that doesnt last with nv below average lacing.
Aroma- Roasted malts, pumpkin, cinnamon, coffee.
Flavor- Big coffee and cinnamon, some vanilla, caramel, nutmeg, pretty sweet.

Growler fill at Albert sons $6. Pours out a cola brown topped with a nice tan head. Nose is great roast pumpkin pie spice toasted malts sweetness and some coffee. Taste is also great a nice nutmeg touch cinnamon pumpkin pie roast malts a nice lice sweet creamy coffee. This is a great one. Not sure how I have never tried it.
Wow. I wasnt expecting this beer to taste as good as it does. It is absolutely amazing!

Draft at Madrones in Frederick, MD. Very dark brown color with beige head. Aroma notes of pumpkin pie spices, coffee, roasted malt and chocolate. Taste adds more coffee and chocolate notes, some nuttiness and vanilla added. Medium body, low-moderate carbonation, tad sticky with spices/sweet finish. Very nice lighter coffee/pumpkin ale.
on tap at Dog & Bull in Croydon - nice dark color. Great spice aroma. Good pumpkin and coffee flavors.

Poured from bomber. 
L: a dark brown, some lighter highlights, and a low beige head with a little lacing and swirl on top. 
S: a lovely whack of cinnamon and nutmeg. The coffee fills out the aroma. 
T: much more coffee in the taste providing bitterness, roasty, the spices mix in wonderfully. Am I getting pumpkin? I think so, the flavours certainly create the feeling. 
F: the body is reasonably light, theres a bit of carbonation up front, the bitter follows through on coffee flavour, a little sweetness. 
O: this is delicious. With these flavours, I would like a bolder fuller sipper, this is pretty easy to drink.
Pours a rich copper color with a pumpkin and cinnamon aroma. Taste is rich with pumpkin flavor, hints of nutmeg and a nice cinnamon aftertaste. A clean beer with a good pumpkin patch flavor.

Pours a super dark brown, almost cola like. Very minimal head that dissipates. Wonderful aroma of rich coffee, pumpkin, pumpkin pie spices and cinnamon. A lot of great flavors make up this beer - mocha, nutmeg, pumpkin, allspice, vanilla and cinnamon.

22 oz. bottle.  Packaged:  08/04/15.  My bottle says 6% ABV.  A deep mahogany pour with a smallish antique white head.  Smells like a fresh piece of pumpkin pie with a cup of coffee!  Plenty of cinnamon, nutmeg, and ginger in the aroma.  Goes down thin to medium-bodied.  The taste starts with a little bit of caramel, molasses, and some pumpkin.  Lots of nutmeg and cinnamon here and there.  Some bitter roasted coffee qualities at the end.  Delicious!

Opaque black with a medium sized, tan head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of cinnamon, nutmeg, coffee, roasted malts, and some cocoa. Taste of cocoa, coffee, roast, pumpkin spices, and a lightly sweet finish.

Bottle @ home. Thanks, Jake. Dark brown, almost black in color, with a bit of khaki foam. Nice coffee nose along with a good bit of roasted malt. Sort of a nutty and vanilla quality to it as well. Sort of a (relatively) mild spice note to it, too. Good sweetness, but not really too strong, and a light bitterness to it as well. Nice beer.

Bomber. Huge nose, spice and coffee, cinnamon, nutmeg, coffee, enormous. Cloudy black with lace. Interesting flavor, some pumpkin, more cinnamon, lots of coffee. Light but full body. Spiced coffee is not really my thing, but decent.

UPDATED: NOV 11, 2015 Smooth pumpkin coffee. Really nice beer. Pumpkin/spice and Coffee/cream are on equal footing. Good beer.   Having now tried all 4 Elysian pumpkins I could find, they are quite a collection.   All 4 are high quality.

651 ml. bottle. Bottled 8/18/15. 6% ABV per the label, so it is a slightly different recipe. Pours a medium, well retained, beige head, with light lacing, over a medium brown (SRM 24) body.....nose is cinnamon, nutmeg, light coffee, toasted malts, minimal hops......taste is moderately sweet, with cinnamon, nutmeg, hints of coffee, light pumpkin, cocoa, minimal hop bitterness.....mouth feel, light almost watery body, no alcohol, low carbonation. The spices and the coffee were gently used as was the pumpkin. The result is a moderately sweet, lightly spiced beer with the coffee adding a bit of intrigue. It is easy drinking and a moderately successful experiment within the pumpkin ale style. BJCP 7/3/12/3/6

Dark red with minimal head and lots of sediment. Nose is pumpkin, cinnamon, coffee. Thin body. Pretty easy to drink, some pumpkin coffee cinnamon kinda thing going on, malty almost reminds me more of a winter ale. Watery. Not really packed with flavor. Ok

Draught @ Brouwers Café in Sep 2014: &nbsp Dark brown with strong ruby hues, thin soapy khaki head, little lacing. &nbsp Cinnamon and nutmeg nose, strong sweetened coffee too. &nbsp Seems like a spicy sweet milk stout. &nbsp Lots of nutmeg on the tongue, and creamer. Coffee is subtle. &nbsp Smooth, but moderate body and mouthfeel. &nbsp Not much about this says pumpkin to me. &nbsp It seems like a nutmeg infused milk or sweet stout. &nbsp Still very enjoyable and sweet. &nbsp Lingering nutmeg and a touch more coffee, make that fru fru coffee. &nbsp Enjoyable.
Bottle from Albertsons. Surprisingly good, mild pumpkin spices, coffee lingers way in the back. Tasty, smooth, welcoming. Perfect fall brew.

Tap at BurgerMania Ebisu. Deep brown with a nice pillowy beige head. Big sweet espresso notes with allspice, clove, nutmeg and cinnamon along with roasted pumpkin. Taste is a little sweet and maybe a bit too heavy on the spice, but the coffee still shines though. As does the pumpkin. I hate pumpkin beers and this is a little too sweet, but I actually liked this. Its a fun beer.

Draught at Burgermania. Medium body, a little syrupy, lots of spicy pumpkin, coffee beans, chocolate cake, cinnamon, allspice, gentle sweet finish. Quite rich and complex, somewhat reminiscent of some tasty xmas brews.

Deep dark brown with a thin rocky beige head. Very aromatic nose of earthy coffee, big cinnamon and nutmeg tones. Smooth earthy sweet flavor with a load of cinnamon and nutmeg, very gentle gingerbread, light pumpkin and just a kiss of coffee. Its semisweet and palatable and quite tasty if youre looking for a pumpkin spice coffee cake-tasting brew.
Pumpkin seed, cinammon smell, the taste is as expected pumpkin, coffee, bitter bitterness with a spicy nutmeg taste on the swallow.

Poured from bottle into a pint glass
 Appearance  The beer pours a deep brown color with a one finger head of a cream colored foam. The head has a decent level of retention, fading over time to leave a lighter level of streaky lace on the sides of the glass.
 Smell  The aroma of the brew is super strong of a cinnamon and nutmeg smell with a decent sum of roasted coffee and some roasted pumpkin. There is a tiny bit of a brown sugar and caramel as well, creating a rather roasty pumpkin pie smell overall.
 Taste  The taste begins with a rather roasty and lightly coffee tinted flavor. The pumpkin is very light upfront with it growing just slightly stronger as the taste advances. The spice however, which is also light upfront, increases to a greater extent than the pumpkin, giving a rather decently strong cinnamon and nutmeg taste to be on the tongue at the end of the taste. Along with the spice flavors comes some flavors of a roasted coffee taste, and with a little bit of caramel and brown sugar taste coming to the tongue at the end, one is left with a rather pleasantly spiced and lightly pumpkin-roasted flavor to linger on the tongue.
 Mouthfeel  The body of the beer is a little bit thinner for a darker pumpkin brew with a carbonation level that is average. A little thicker of a body may have been slightly nicer for the pumpkin and roasted flavors, but with that said, the lighter body was rather nice for the rich spice, so overall the feel was rather decent.
 Overall- While not as much coffee as I would have expected and with a rather strong showing of spice, it was still overall a very enjoyable and drinkable beer. I would certainly get this again. Another good pumpkin brew by Elysian.
On draft at Montana Brewing Company. Pours a murky brown. Spicy nose, dominated by cloves. Flavors of pumpkin pie spices, some pumpkin, and subtle coffee? Smooth finish.

Botte at home with family, courtesy of my sister. Thanks Dani! Pour is deep brown with a small tan head and good lacing. Huge vanilla, toffee, pumpkin, nutmeg, sweet potatoes, cinnamon, allspice, and graham crackers in the world. Taste is big nutmeg, vanilla, allspice, light cocoa, coffee, bready, some brown sugar with a slightly spicy finish. Medium body with high carbonation. Solid pumpkin offering.

Bottle, deep brown beer, skiff of cream colored head, a little lace. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, dark malt, punkin pie . Taste is sweet coffee, milk chocolate, vanilla, and seasonal spices. Palate is smooth, this almost feels like nitro. Finish is bitter sweet. This is better than I thought it would be.

Bottle: Pours a muddy brown, similar to French roast, topped with a large creamy beige head. The noise is spicy, but not over the top. Pumpkin pie type spices, nutmeg and cinnamon, with a little bit of mocha. There is a strong resemblance to the coffee shop drink; coffee and mocha with nutmeg and cinnamon. Not too much of either part, fairly balanced. I think I like best the level of spice, but I find myself wanting more espresso. Overall a good start to the pumpkin beer season.
Bottle. Dark brown, with a biege head. Lots of pumpkin, lots of spice, nutmeg, allspice, and coffee. Thin body. Ok, it would be better with more malt, abv and body.

Bomber from Kings Liquor in Orange County. Pours darkly ruddy with a beige head. Smooth coffee/cinnamon aroma. Med + body. Very much coffee and cinnamon for flavor. Very smmoth and tasty, but not exactly beer as expected. Great flavor.
Bottle shared by bhensonb. Pours dark brown with a thick tan head and a cinnamon and pumpkin aroma. There is an interesting smoked malt flavor with coffee and spices.

Pours dark with attractive ruby edges, thin mocha head that reduces quickly but leaves a bit of skim.
Good nose of coffee, cinnamon, chai, burnt caramel. Taste is creamy coffee with slight pumpkin and pie spices, minor cherry fizz, pie crust. The effect is close to the name, a thin-bodied cappuccino with a small splash of pumpkin spice.
The slight bitterness that comes through is more akin to cappuccino than to the harsh grounds that afflict many coffee beers. Overall, if presented as a coffee beer, it would be very close to the top of that category.
What its not is an especially pumpkin beer, as that takes a definite backseat. Mixing it with The Great Pumpkin improves it.
Bottle compliments of Indiana_Red: Choco-pumpkin aroma and flavor with a definite earthiness about it as well. While not a fan of many of the pumpkin beers, I actually enjoyed this.

Draft pour pint at the collective. Not surprised at all that this is the top rated Elysian pumpkin offering. Damn tasty stuff. Pours a slightly muddy brown color with an off white foam head. Huge pumpkin, Chai spice aroma. Delicious, smooth pumpkin, light vanilla and spice end loaded flavor. Excellent beer. Ill drink this any day of the year. Love it.

Bottle. This is the best pumpkin beer in the world? Are we sure? I think this is a coffee beer, and I think people like coffee beers better than they like pumpkin beers, so this is a "pumpkin beer even I can like," maybe thats what people are thinking. Its fine, its not bad, but for me there are a lot better pumpkin beers out there.
BOttle, clear dark brown, with a quick fizzy head. Nice mix of pumpin, spice and chocolate in the aroma. The nutmeg/spice flavors are prominent and the body is a bit thin. Nice blend.
bottle thanks to Shad, yea this is exactly what you think it is, Strong pumpkin, strong beer, no body. Very thin, all adjuncts!

Bottle from iron abbey. Pours cola brown with a small whitish head and a lot of floaters. The aroma is primarily coffee bean and grinds. Not a ton of the pumpkin . The taste has a nice blend of pie spices, big mocha and coffee, sweet full finish. Well done!
Cinnamon and pumpkin spice aroma. Smooth coffee and pumpkin flavor. Easy drinker with lots of flavor for the ABV. Tasted at 61°F.

Bottle. Ruby/dark brown, transparent edges. Aroma is pumpkin pie and nutmeg. The coffee and dark malt come in the taste on the finish. Lactose, cream, cinnamon, and graham cracker all show up as well. The mouthfeel is a little thin but, it fits the flavors and keeps them from being too heavy. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Deep brown pour off white head light lacing ..., amazing aroma of cinnamon, nutmeg, coffee, roasted malts, chocolate, vanilla and caramel wow .... Taste is of vanilla, coffee, cinnamon, nutmeg, chocolate and roasted/caramel malts .... Sweet and bitter with a nice flavor profile but if this beer tastes as good as it smelled it would be a world beater ..... Body is thin, finish is sweet with a lingering caramel malt, coffee and the cinnamon/nutmeg

Bottle. Thin and very dark brown, with a silky half-finger of light tan head. Aroma is very nice: cinnamon sugar, bran, mild espresso, burnt pie crust, lactose. Flavor is similar, with some tanginess. Big cinnamon and nutmeg, smoother cocoa and burnt toast in the back end. Some milk sweetness throughout. More nutty coffee bean flavor emerges as it warms. A little thin in body. Very nice spice blend -- the girlfriend said it was like Halloween and friendship and love.

22 oz. bottle shared by phaleslu. Pours a slightly hazy cola brown color with a small off white head. The aroma and flavor have coffee, some fleshy pumpkin, roasted malt,spices, nutmeg, cinnamon, ashy, pipe tobacco, some strange interaction with everything has me distracted, I found this difficult to rate because I had trouble deciding what the strange flavor was.

22 oz. bottle via trade. Pours a hazy brownish amber color with a small off-white head that leaves spots of lace and settles into a ring. The coffee gives this one an earthiness beyond the simple roast, along with a faint pepper - yes, were trying it several months late - along with nutmeg, cinnamon, ginger, chocolate, toast, and brown sugar. Light-bodied, with low to moderate carbonation and an earthy, spicy mouthfeel. Ill give it an extra point for the benefit of the doubt; even in its advanced age, its a good beer.

22oz bottle, thanks to phaleslu for sharing. Hazy brown red color. Thin off-white head. Some loose bits of lace. Dark fruit, caramel, some cappuccino. Mild milk chocolate. Medium-plus body. Kind of slick. Lighter carbonation. Moderate sweet. Light bitter. Interesting, alright pumpkin ale. Really interesting aroma, but I think this could have been better fresh. Showing some signs of age here.

Cinammon cappuccino aroma followed with a bit if candied pumpkin. Brown color, clean appearance. Flavor is sweeter and has more pumpkin and dry cinammon spice; coffee is reserved, but there; seems a bit thin, but it is only a 5.0% beer and delivers quite a bit of taste for the alcohol content.
Great aroma, it smells like a pumpkin latte with clove and cinnamon. Good flavor also. Sweet with pumpkin pie spice and mild coffee with milk. Smooth palate. Good.

Tasty taste. No real lacing, but a quality color (walnut) and a small tan head that disappears. Aroma is of freshly ground coffee, and some allspice. Sits pretty heavy on the tongue, residual sweetness in the aftertaste, some coffee bitterness more than hop bitterness, pumpkin ale still present but second fiddle.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma was pumpkin spiced coffee with a dash of nutmeg. Flavor of roasted coffee, cinnamon, pumpkin, nutmeg and fall spices. Creamy texture, medium body, medium carbonation

On tap at Barcade Philly.
Appearance: Deep chestnut body with a short and quickly dissipating head.
Aroma: Smells exactly like a pumpkin coffee. Cinnamon, nutmeg, and coffee with a dash of caramel and some sweet malts.
Taste: Mild with a slightly watery intro. Leads to cinnamon and coffee. Finish is great, intro lacks.
Palate: Medium bodied, mild to moderately carbonated.
Overall: This could be near-perfect if it had a slightly beefier malt base. Aroma is incredible.

From tap. Pours hazy brown with a small tan head. Aroma is roasted malty and slight spiced to herbal. Herbal, cinnamon, sweet and caramelish. Toffee and caramelish. Bitter and toasted malty into the finish. Very interesting.

Thanks to 5000 for sending this bottle my way. Brown pour with a tan head. The aroma has some cream. brown sugar, coffee and pumpkin. The flavor is a mix of pumpkin and coffee. Fairly sweet with some creamy cinnamon and brown sugar notes. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Great beer.
Dark brown in color, hazy with a thin white head. Tons of aroma and flavor. This was a thick dark beer with added coffee and tons of spices. Nice fun beer by Elysian once again.
Bottle - Spice, chocolate and coffee. Clear dark copper with a light brown head. Spice, coffee and chocolaty roast. Finish has some cinnamon heat. Like something from Starbucks, very nice.

Pours an extremely dark brown, almost black. Head is 1/3 inch and khaki colored. Head retention is good and lacing is very good.

Smell is big on pumpkin and pumpkin spices, cinnamon and nutmeg dominate. Not really getting any coffee. Roasted caramel malt is also in the mix, alcohol and hops are not.

Taste is of standard pumpkin ale, lots of cinnamon, nutmeg, and allspice. Caramel malts add some roasted flavor, even getting some pie crust. Not getting much coffee, which is disappointing. Easy going down at 5% abv. 

Mouthfeel is light and somewhat thin. Head added a tiny bit of texture, beer was well carbonated. 

Overall this was a pretty good pumpkin beer. Not too sweet or overly spiced. Only wished coffee was more pronounced. I got almost no coffee which I think would have really set this beer apart. Regardless, it was worth trying, hoping theyll release this annually and up the dose of coffee
Holy coffee choco pumpy love in the nose. Lovely spice of cinnamon and sweet love. Taste is exactly as beer is described but mouthfeel seems a bit thin. overall pretty tasty but a glass is enough.

Bottle: Poured a dark black brown with red edges, head is tan and dissipated fast. Aroma is pumpkin spice coffee like, very inviting. Loads of nutmeg, cinnamon spice hits me first with pumpkin and coffee towards the finish.

@ The Ginger Man à Manhattan. Une bière noire avec une mousse beige. Un nez remplit dépices de tarte à la citrouille,de muscade, clou, cannelle et de café. La bouche est tout aussi remplit de saveurs, une finale sur les épices et le café. La texture est crémeuse. Un régal. La réponse au PSL de Starbuck, en mieux.
Almost black with a brown head. Good stuff! Bold pumpkin and spice flavors with great coffee notes and chocolate. Silky body, lactose?

Pours dark brown almost black with a tan head. Aroma is coffee, vanilla, nutmeg, and cinnamon. Dark roasted malt flavor with milky coffee, cinnamon, nutmeg, cloves and vanilla. Dark black coffee bitter finish.

Wow! I was disappointed at first w/ the $12 price tag & only 5% abv but this was well worth it! Very dark pour w/ a tan head that leaves nice lacing. The aroma is quite roasty w/ some cinnamon & nutmeg undertones. The taste is right on w/ the aroma. Quite roasty & coffee like w/ a touch of spice that really sets this apart. The mouthfeel is exquisite - creamy, light, & oh so flavorful for 5%. Awesome beer!

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2014 On tap at Rattle n Hum NY. Pours a dark brown with small tan head. Nose shows lovely espresso, pumpkin, chocolate and light caramel. Taste has coffee and chocolate up front, rounding out with pumpkin and light spices. My kind of pumpkin beer! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at Max's in Fell's Point, Baltimore, MD. 

Opaque, dark rusty brown with a khaki head and excellent lacing. 

Aroma of allspice, cinnamon, cloves, pumpkin, coffee, nutmeg, gingerbread and toffee. 

Taste of gingerbread, sweet toffee, chocolate, coffee, nutmeg, orange, cinnamon, cloves, pumpkin and raisins. 

Medium body and low/medium carbonization.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Sample at Kurtkeller 017: Pumpkin-tastic 02 on 10/13/2014. Brownish-black color with a medium foamy tan head that diminishes gradually. Aroma of pumpkin spices, malt and coffee. Light-bodied with flavors of roasted coffee, cinnamon and malt. The finish is roasty with a pumpkin coffee aftertaste. Pretty good all around.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2014 Draft at Moriartys. Pitch black pour with a tight layer of light beige foam. Interesting mix of a creamy dark roast coffee stout and a pumpkin ale. Good mouthfeel. Feels bigger than its listed ABV might suggest - though still easy drinking. Very well balanced. Exceptionally smooth. Really quite good!

Wow! Pours unclear dark amber with a creamy beige head. Aroma brings earthy pumpkin and smooth sweet pumpkin coffee, so nice. Flavors of warming pumpkin and sweet fall spices and the mocha as a delicious not overly sweet beautiful backbone. So nice on a creamy body.

Picked up a single 22-oz bomber at City Vineyard in Billings, Montana. Pours an opaque dark orange brown colored brew with an off-white head that slowly dissipates and leaves behind some excellent lacing. Aroma of pumpkin latte, a hint of pumpkin bread and toasted coffee. Taste is medium to full bodied with more coffee presence as the beer warms up. Finish is semi-sweet with more cinnamon, nutmeg and coffee aftertaste.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2015 This pours lighter than expected, and initially smells lighter on the coffee than expected. Spices are VERY well done...exactly as expected from Elysian. This one separates itself a little in that the coffee aspect of the beer really is cappuccino (as advertised) and not coffeecoffeecoffee, like most. Ill usually dig the coffee beers either way but they really nailed the pumpkin cappuccino thing here.

With Z and J on Halloween night, pours a dark black pour with no head. Nose is coffee, chocolate and intense cinnamon !! Taste is sweet cinnamon, almost like a liquid cinnamon roll, with a nutmeg finish. Absolutely a liquid tasty sweet dessert with the coffe included. quaff score 8 / 10

Bomber on Halloween night. Pours a dark brown with a tan head and great aroma of nice roasty coffee and pumpkin along with lots of pleasant cinnamon. Taste is delicious, lots of pronounced cinnamon, nutmeg, and spices with tons of nice roasted coffee, gingerbread, and pumpkin pie notes into the spiced, coffee finish. Delicious, very drinkable brew

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2015 Bottle from Craft Beer Base shared by Roy. Served in a snifter. A dark brown pour verging on black with a sliver of a light beige head. Bready, gingerbread, pumpkin, spice, coffee a truly fantastic aroma. Med-full bodied with a bit of a rough carbonation. The best balance of pumpkin and coffee Ive seen in a beer. This is excellent. Very subtly spicing with espresso, truly wonderful.

Bittle thanks to michaelinwa. Dark brown pour with a small, big bubbled head that fades to a messy ring. Great aroma of light roast coffee, cinnamon, nutmeg, and vanilla ice cream. Tastes slightly sweet. Like a sweetened, spiced iced coffee. Medium body. Mouthfeel could be better. Could be a little smoother and creamier. Still a very good beer.
Keg. Coffee, pumpkin, smooth, low on spiciness, some clove I think, cinnamon, but not over the top. Nice. Surprisingly good. Strange mix, but I like it. Bit of toffee too.

Bomber. Coffee aroma with notes of cinnamon, nutmeg and pumpkin. Pours very dark brown with a medium, light brown head and some lacing. Starts well with the spices mentioned above as well as some pumpkin. Finishes fairly smooth with the spices still adding character briefly until the coffee takes over and clings to the palate after the sip. Starts well but my dislike of strong coffee ruins the finish for me.

Dark brown color. Big nose of nutmeg cinnamon and coffee. Sweet, but great blend. Smells like Starbucks latest overly sweet seasonal offering, but so much better. The mouth is light sweet, lots of nutmeg and cinnamon. Smooth. Lingering nutmeg finish. Fantastic.

Bomber. Pumpkin beer #2. Aroma is cinnamon, pumpkin, chocolate; coffee is there, but weak. Pours cola brown with a medium beige head with good retention. Taste is sweet, lightly tart with light bitterness in the finish; roasty. Meaty pumpkin and cinnamon are strong; only a hint of coffee. Body is fairly thin. Good, not great. That tartness is really weird and the coffee isnt strong enough.

22 oz bottle- Pours black with a nice mocha colored head and cobwebby lace. Aroma is pumpkin spice, some coffee and malt. Taste is mocha, pumpkin spice, not much raw pumpkin here, more nutmeg and lots of cinnamon. Not the best pumpkin from this brewery, but still good.

Bottle to glass. Pours a deep brown color with a light tan head. Aroma is chocolate, cookie dough, pumpkin, light coffee. Flavor is pretty similar, like a chocolate cookie with hints of pumpkin and coffee. Medium body with a lingering chocolate cookie, light pumpkin. Definitely my favorite of the pumpkin varieties so far. Excellent beer. Also like Elysians Dark O the Moon. Similar, but without the coffee.

22 oz bottle poured into a glass. Shared by my friend Mike, thanks! Black with light tan head. Aromas of pumpkin, coffee, spices, a bit of caramel. Tastes of dark chocolate, pumpkin, spices, coffee, light roast, caramel/toffee. Medium body with a dry finish. Very tasty. Pumpkin and spices are nicely balanced.
Bomber from Tacoma boys. Pours dark brown, light tan head. Scent is all coffee beans and spice. Taste is a lot of coffee also. Brown sugar and a little pumpkin spice. Very tasty.

Wow. Nice. Solid coffee stout. That by itself is great. But perfect pumpkin spice infusion. Recommended. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Ive gotten overwhelmed with pumpkin beers lately but I have heard good things of this one so I decided to pick up a bottle. Big aromas of coffee and pumpkin spice, basically a pumpkin spice latte in beer form. Huge flavor with a sweet taste bit not sickening. I can definitely tolerate a few of these a year.
Pretty good for a pumpkin beer. Cappuccino really has strong presence here. Pours black with decent head and lacing. Light bitter finish. Some light clove. Some resin. Tap at scion.
Good stuff. Nice nose. Coffee up front and pumkin in the back. Needs more bittering.

Poured from bottle to glass. Dark hue with creamy tan head that settled. Aroma is sugar, cinnamon, coffee, nutmeg, pumpkin. Mouthfeel is great with a medium body and zesty carbonation. Taste is sweet throughout with a spice astringentness in the following. Overall this is a very nice brew.

Bottle. Pours brown with deep red hues and off-white head. Aroma is strong brown sugar, vanilla, cinnamon, nutmeg, nuts. Taste is sweet, bitter finish, medium-bodied, medium carbonation, creamy. Very good.

Bottled. Pours black with a small light tan head and lacing. Aroma is as advertised big pumpkin and coffee notes mixing with each other rather than having either one overwhelming the other. Cinnamon and vanilla and chocolate also come through. Flavor is pumpkin cinnamon sweetness first then very quickly turning into roasted coffee flavors. The pumpkin and other spices tone down the coffee bitterness so that you get a sweet pumpkin aftertaste along with a distinct spice character. Mouthfeel is unremarkable. This is one of the few beers to pull off both pumpkin and dark roasted flavors and have both elements come through big time. Well done.

It looks like someone tried to rub off the date at the bottom of the bottle but I think it said: "08/29/14." Not sure how long Elysian has been doing this but Im glad I noticed it.
This was poured into a tulip.
The appearance had a dark brown complexion, close to black color. A thin off white foamy head had a decent retention that dissipated at a nice pace. Light stringy lacing clung nicely around the glass.
The smell was a pure strong coffee/slightly leaning towards the cappuccino sweet side of a light cinnamon, and then allspice and then nutmeg.
The taste took those flavors to town to enliven and thoroughly sweeten yet allow a slight roast of coffee to enter nicely.
On the palate, this one sat about a medium on the body with a pure sticky sweet pumpkin/ginger spicy aftertaste and then a good watery sticky sweet pumpkin coffee finish. I say this was a sipper for the most part.
Overall, I say this was a very nicely done pumpkin ale with a ton of other things going on to ensure that Elysian is pretty much the King of Pumpkin ales. Of course I would have this again!

Growler from Total wine. Nice brown/black color, not much head. Nice nose of some spices, pumpkin and cappuccino. Taste is super smooth blend of cappuccino and pumpkin.... Very well done. Lots of roasted malts and spices. Body is reminds me of a porter. Easy to drink. I thought the alcohol content was closer to 6.5 but either way....great brewski. Hope I can score some more!

On tap at Elizabeth Station, pours a fairly clear deep dark mahogany with a small tan head. Aroma brings out a mix of pumpkin spice and cocoa. Flavour is much the same, with notes of nutmeg, cinnamon and cocoa powder. Surprisingly well-constructed given that I dont like pumpkin beerd generally, though Elysian certainly are the masters of them. Nice stuff.

From bottle. Deep dark brown color. Aroma is cold-brewed coffee, chai spices, and pumpkin pie filling. Taste is nutmeg, cinnamon, light chili, coffee, and pumpkin puree. Seems like the beer version of a pumpkin latte, which is great.

22 oz bottle. Deep brown with a beige head. Nose is pumpkin, nutmeg, cinnamon, vanilla and coffee. Medium body with a soft buzz. Taste is coffee, cinnamon, nutmeg and cocoa. Not getting much pumpkin. Ill be looking for this one on nitro.
On tap at the Blue Dog in Chalfont. Poured a dark brown color with a smaller sized off white head. Spice, coffee, pumpkins, roast, and some earth. Not bad for a Pumpkin beer

22oz bomber from Crossroads. Poured a clear dark brown color with a finger of creamy light tan head. Aroma of rich espresso grounds, cinnamon, nutmeg, vanilla bean, and a hint of roasted pumpkin. Taste mimics the nose with lots of black coffee up front, and even more cinnamon as it warms up. Great beer

Bomber from Whole Foods Plymouth. Pours hazy mahogany/ruby through direct light, with 2-finger tan head that laces well. Nose is like pumpkin pie, exploding on the nose with an intense aroma, with dark malt, pie spice, and sweet pumpkin notes. Tastes delicious. Lemme tell ya about this beer, Bob Griese. Incredible pumpkin pie flavor, plus dark malt and coffee, but mostly delicious pumpkin pie. This is one of the best pumpkin beers I have ever quaffed. Finishes complex, dense on the palate, and super smooth. Get ya some.

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown color with a moderate tan head on there. Nose has enough coffee in there to completely cover a cup of coffee, but has just a hint of some sweet pumpkin coming through. Taste is slightly sweet, with coffee, chocolate and pumpkin flavors highlighted. Very good.

Bottle from Belmont Station. 

A: Dark mahogany with a creme colored head and some lacing. A few bubbles. 

N: Nutmeg, pumpkin, cinnamon, all-spice, a touch of coffee, toffee, graham cracker, and then a whooooole ton of cola. Cola, dominates as this warms, too. 

T: Bready, sweet, and spicy. Not much bitterness nor coffee here. 

M: Light body, moderate carb, no alcohol for this light sipper. 

O: Night owl with a hint of coffee. I wish there was more body and an appreciable coffee flavor. Might be some bottle variation for this one.
Bottle thanks to Matt. Dark brown pour, brown head, medium body and smooth slick texture. Iced pumpkin spice latte. Loads of coffee, spices not overpowering. Really quite tasty.

Bomber. Dark brownish black pour with a sudsy layer of tan foam. Inviting aroma of chai tea, coffee beans, dark chocolate and pumpkin. Flavor is a blend of medium roast coffee, pumpkin and Mexican hot chocolate with some nutmeg and cinnamon in the finish. Excellent Pumpkin/Coffee ale hybrid with loads of flavor and balance for a 5%er.
Pours cola brown with aroma of coffee, spice, and touch of pumpkin. Lots of coffee flavor with spice in the background. A rather excellent beer.

Nice aroma of cinnamon, coffee, nutmeg. The appearance is deep brown, red hue, off white head. The flavor is coffee, cinnamon, spicy. The finish s roast, spices. Medium/thick in body. Nicely done. Works better than I though it would.

From a tap at the brewery. The pour is a dark red with minimum white head. Simple notes; Pumpkin, coffee, milk stout like.its like a brunch dessert beer as I could not see myself drinking six of these but maybe a 20 oz at an end of a meal.
Nice sweet coffee aroma, a good creamy body with a nice coffee malt taste. Mild pumpkin hint, good stuff

Bomber shared by Ed5388 on my bday. Poured a thinner super deep dark mahogany brown with a frothy super light beige head. Aroma is nice, lots of cinnamon and spice along with coffee and a hint of pumpkin pie with cool whip topping. Only medium body but with bubbly carbonation this seems bigger than it is, average duration on the aftertaste. Flavor is the same as the aroma, coffee and spice dominate, hint of pumpkin pie and well done muffins. Good stuff.

Bomber from Whole Foods. Pours a pitch black color with a medium greyish head. A big roast coffee lactose nose, light spice. Big cinnamon, lactose, heavy coffee, a nice palate, some metallic roast. Very good. Wait, this is only 5%, how? Wow. I mean, this tastes like much more. Super flavorful. Damn, this is an awesome beer. A home run for what they wanted.
Bottle. Brown pour with tan head. Coffee, spice, pumpkin and sweet aromas. Cinnamon, pumpkin and cappuccino flavors, sweet. More enjoyable as a beer then as a coffee.

I love coffee and pumpkin beer and Elysian married this combo perfectly. Pour is dark mahogany almost black with a tall cream head. Aroma is sweet with coffee and spices. The best part of this beer is you all the ingredients its not a beer that you think wheres the pumpkin or wheres coffee you get it all. If Starbucks made beer this would be it.

22 oz bomber, served in a pint glass. Pours deep brown with thick fluffy mocha head. Aroma is medium chocolate malt, some coffee, and fresh sweet pumpkin that lingers throughout. Taste is thin brown malt, mild chocolate quickly following, with only a faint note of espresso on the finish. Pleasant milk chocolate notes throughout. Plenty of depth of flavor, though could stand for a higher abv to match the taste - 5% leaves this a bit unbalanced and not really worthy of $9 per bomber.

Bottle picked up at the COOP over the weekend, but all the usual haunts will see these this year. Poured into my FunkFest goblet.. thin black brew with an off-white head that shows pretty proper retention and lacing.

Elysian nails the nose .. Chai spiced latte?? Sweet spiced but nothing overwhelming on the palate.. the coffee notes envelope the sweet spices ... No "non-beer drinker" would ever believe this is actually beer.

Sweet cinnamon and lesser clove... "mace?" and nutmeg... punctuated by a nice smack of dry coffee... Jesus, this is tasty and I dont normally like pumpkin beers at all and only "sorta" appreciate coffee brews. Punkuccino works very... VERY well.

Light body... but the intent of this bottle is to really appreciate the season... I dig it, but there are going to be people that fall in love forever.

Outstanding in the field... Awesome for what it is.

Trying not to be influenced by the hype. Bomber. An $11 bomber. Pours dark brown with thin off white head. Aroma is potent. Half coffee and cinnamon. First sip and wow this is wimpy and limp body. Super thin. I was expecting imperial stout thickness and complexity. Flavor is, again, very coffee and cinnamon and nutmeg. Pumpkin? Not gonna lie, what does pumpkin even taste like? I love the flavors nonetheless and they are pretty well balanced. Its just a way less intense than i was expecting especially for 11 freaking dollars. Should have noticed the 5% before buying.
Smells of cinnamon and spice, some coffee. Looks like a cup of pour over. Amazing flavors, coffee, spices, but it's like drinking a slightly mineralized ice coffee. Very thought provoking beer.

Poured from a 22 found at Whole Foods in Tanasbourne. As soon as the bottle was opened the room smelled like candy, I was pretty excited about this beer. Overall, the combination of the sugar, spice and coffee made this one of the best "gimmicky" beers I have had. Yum!

22 oz bottle from Whole Foods in Hillsboro, OR. Initial nose has subtle coffee, fall spices, and Halloween candy corn. After tasting, it has a much stronger coffee and spice nose, with hints of gingerbread and pretzels. The mouthfeel starts creamy, but then the spices give it a slightly astringent finish and make the beer feel more boozy than it really is. Taste is sweet, robust, and dare I say salty? Great beer!
draft at Blue Monk, Buffalo NY. Chocolatety brown pour. cappuccino and pumpkin spice in both flavor & aroma. creamy mouthfeel, great flavor, very tasty. Nice beer

Brown,lasting beige head.Nose of brown sugar.sweel malt & allspice.Overly sweet with pumpkin,allspice and strong coffee flavors
Interesting, but far too sweet

On tap at St Augustines on The Drive in Vancouver. Very dark brown, nearly black, with a bit of off-white head. Coffee on the nose. Ummm...the combination of coffee and pumpkin-spice flavours yields one of the more interesting October/slash/pumpkin style beers of this or any season. The coffee infusion adds the punch that pumpkin spices usually lack. I quite like this!

Tap at Tangle Town. Pours a low haze, red amber. Medium foam with webby lacing. Nose is fresh fall spice medley. Taste is sugary, spicy, dark chili chocolate. Sweet overall, but the beer works as intended. Approved by my pumpkin beer loving wife.

Deep rubescent body with mocha-cappucino head. A dark beauty in a glass. lovely pumpkin-spiced coffee aromas coolly titillate the nose. the effect is like a chilled, canned frappucino drink, with pumpkin spiced mixed in, but it is rather heavy on the sweetener. The body also takes of pumpkin frappucino. Artificial sweetness definitely detracts for me, but this still manages to be a decadent pleasure.

Draft, Snallygaster. Creamy beige head atop dark brown body. Aroma is moderately sweet, coffee, some nutmeg, light allspice, roast, faint peat. Taste is moderately sweet, coffee, some caramel, some roast, light nutmeg. Medium-full body, some stickiness.

Draft at Snallygaster 2013. Poured a very dark brown color with a nice dark tan head. Aroma was very powerful, enjoyable, very nicely brewed coffee - not overtly bitter - nicely spiced. Pumpkin in there! This one had a nice, enjoyable coffee taste like a very tasty pumpkin pie spice latte. This was fantastic.

Draft. Hazy dark brown color, beige head. Aroma is a beautiful combination of freshly brewed coffee and light pumpkin pie spice. Taste is a lightly spice latte frappee mochachino not made with yuppie soy milk. Absolutely delicious.

Pours amber to brown.

Smell big coffee roast.

Taste is like cold coffee, lots of coffee flavor without the burnt roast taste.

Light to medium body.

Reminds me a lot of split shot. Great beer.

Tap @ GPBF... Poured brownish, hazy with a thin head. This was an amazing concoction. Tasted like the pumpkin spiced coffee drinks you get Starbucks. Which normally arent my thing, but came off awesome in this beer. Some pumpkin spice, sweetness and rich coffee on this one.

Draft at sb. Pours a murky medium brown with a dense and creamy tan head. Big sweet pie spice nose, no real coffee or malt presence. Creamy medium body with flabby carb. Sweet pie spice mid palate with mild molasses overtones. Sweet finish.
